@asereda-gs , yes I have addressed the review comments. W.r.t change from user = 'sa', I couldn't find another way of setting that in the test. Please review the changes.
@siddharthteotia there are build failures. Can you pls fix them ?

@vlsi , I have rebased and added a test case to test Filter and Project MultiJoin merge rules work with any implementations of Filter and Project as opposed to just LogicalFilter and LogicalProject. For this I added CustomFilter and CustomProject as implementations of Filter and Project interfaces. Similarly, I had to pass in a custom RelBuilderFactory to SqltoRelConverter config as by default it uses RelFactories.LOGICAL_BUILDER which has all the default factories. The test case has implementations of Custom filter and project factory.

One problem I have been facing is that SqlToRelConverter has hardcoded the filter factory to be used as default filter factor in RelFactories and thus the custom implementation doesn't get used for Filter. If you look at the test case plan in RelOptRulesTest.xml, you can see that the plan now has "MyProject" instead of "LogicalProject" but it is still having "LogicalFilter" because of this hardcoded factory in SqlToRelConverter at line#990

I couldn't really find a way of extracting the configured filter factor in SqlToRelConverter config -- something like config.getRelBuilderFactory.getFilterFactory(). AFAIK, there is probably no way of getting the specific factory class and using that instead of hardcoding to LogicalFilter factory.

Can you please advise how this can be fixed?

> @siddharthteotia there are build failures. Can you pls fix them ?

@asereda-gs , addressed the build failures. I hadn't resolved conflicts properly during rebase. They are fixed now.
Thank you!

SqlToRelConverter should use the RelBuilderFactory provided in the configuration. As you observed there are places where this does not happen. To me this appears like a bug so you could maybe fix it as part of this PR. With a first glance it does not look so complicated to replace hardcoded factories with those in the configuration.

> I need something like config.getRelBuilderFactory().getFilterFactory()

The factories are inside the created RelBuilder. Can't you use something like:
`final RelNode filter = relBuilder.filter(convertedWhere2);`
or
 `relBuilder.push(bb.root);`
 `final RelNode filter = relBuilder.filter(convertedWhere2);`
for instance?
I didn't really look how the relBuilder is used previously but I guess should be something similar.

Since [PR#981](https://github.com/apache/calcite/pull/981) is not updated since Dec, I open this pull request based on it with some fix-up. You can also find some comments in the [JIRA#2754]( https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-2754).

Closing this PR, since it has been resolved in commit: https://github.com/apache/calcite/commit/136c9c5d75cf7b0809c3bde3525956d2c58470c7, feel free to reopen it if you don't think so.

Oops I somehow missed your ping @hsyuan :(, reviewing now.

Overall I am +1, besides a minor issue (might not be an issue?):

If I test the code correctly, following SQL is still not optimized:

```sql
-- 1. bottom count has only an empty group set
-- 2. query is executed on empty table/set
select sum(c) from (select count("empid") as c from "hr"."emps" where "deptno" < 0)
```

I guess this is because following fail condition is a little aggressive:
https://github.com/apache/calcite/blob/b5c6e25b131fcfcd5a640641401a8cb61820ad72/core/src/main/java/org/apache/calcite/rel/rules/AggregateMergeRule.java#L121-L123

Could we ensure the optimization happens on such a SQL too? (since it looks like a simplest one)

@zhztheplayer Good catch.  This is a special case that we can't just simply combining the 2 aggregates into a single aggregate, because the row type for top agg with SUM is integer nullable, but if we replace with COUNT, the row type becomes integer not nullable, we will see type mismatch assertion error. Unless we add a new Project operator on top to forcefully make it nullable, which seems like a hack.

Thank you for the explanation! I think It is indeed hacky to transform the COUNT to something nullable.  So I'm with you in general.

Maybe there is possibility to apply optimization to SUM0(empty group)-COUNT(empty group) relation, but the algebras seems to be rarely produced by SQL so it is likely not a very important case.
I am not sure whether it is worth doing for SUM0, because `SUM0` is not a standard sql aggregate function, and it only exists in Calcite.

> I am not sure whether it is worth doing for SUM0, because `SUM0` is not a standard sql aggregate function, and it only exists in Calcite.

Agreed. Thanks for the work, Haisheng!

@hsyuan I have updated the pull request to address your comments. Thanks for taking a look.

In future, when you make code changes after a review, could you add new commits rather than amending existing commits? It's easier to review the deltas.

(Obviously you need to force-push in order to rebase or change the commit message.)

As a reviewer I am happy to squash and rebase (as long as rebase is clean or relatively easy).

I'm re-reviewing now, hopefully will be able to commit to master, so don't touch the branch.
Sure. Thank you for your kindly reminder @julianhyde .
LGTM, +1.
BTW, does it not cause build broken if some non-reserved keywords are not added to `config.fmpp`?

Thank you very much for the review, @chunweilei !

Address your comment:
> Does it not cause build broken if some non-reserved keywords are not added to `config.fmpp`?

No currently it doesn't. If you meant automating the build to correct the inconsistency of non-reserved keyword list among different parsers, I'll support this idea. At least at this time, the default parser's non-reserved keywords are all added to other parsers, and it ensures that if a query is parsed successfully by core parser, it should also be safely parsed by other parsers.

And I see the Calcite connection property `nullEqualToEmpty` is no longer in use in the PR. The property is introduced by the fix of [CALCITE-2358](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-2358). Please double-check to make sure we don't introduce any problem that are already solved before.
This PR supersedes https://github.com/apache/calcite/pull/969
I left some comments in the JIRA.

@vlsi @zhztheplayer Can you help review the PR? Appreciate it.

Thanks for your work, @chunweilei . 

Just my 2 cents: can we leverage the existing field `ProjectJoinTransposeRule#preserveExprCondition`? Currently we pass a lambda expression that always returns `true`. But maybe that way is more like a work around, I am not sure.
Besides, should we push down RexOver's operands? Say, inside the expression `sum(x + x) over ()`, `x + x` is strong and can be preserved into Project.

> Besides, should we push down RexOver's operands? Say, inside the expression sum(x + x) over (), x + x is strong and can be preserved into Project.

Yes, currently it will push down the operands. I will add a test about it.

I am not sure. I run a case 
```sql
select e.sal + b.comm,
sum(b.sal + b.sal) over (partition by b.job)
from emp e join bonus b
on e.ename = b.ename and e.deptno = 10
```
The planner gives me 
```
LogicalProject(EXPR$0=[+($1, $6)], EXPR$1=[SUM(+($5, $5)) OVER (PARTITION BY $4 RANGE BETWEEN UNBOUNDED PRECEDING AND UNBOUNDED FOLLOWING)])
  LogicalJoin(condition=[AND(=($0, $3), $2)], joinType=[inner])
    LogicalProject(ENAME=[$1], SAL=[$5], ==[=($7, 10)])
      LogicalTableScan(table=[[CATALOG, SALES, EMP]])
    LogicalProject(ENAME=[$0], JOB=[$1], SAL=[$2], COMM=[$3])
      LogicalTableScan(table=[[CATALOG, SALES, BONUS]])
```
Oops, I will look into it. Also check whether we can use  `ProjectJoinTransposeRule#preserveExprCondition`
@zhztheplayer Appreciate your kindly review.

Therefore, this change will do harm, so I'll close the current PR.

Changes look good to me. Are we agreed to add all these functions to standard sql operator table? JSON_STORAGE_SIZE and others look like MySQL specific. @zhztheplayer

> Are we agreed to add all these functions to standard sql operator table? 

If the add of `MysqlSqlOperatorTable` should be done in some other independent patches (maybe in the fix of [CALCITE-2846](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-2846)?), I think it's not unacceptable to put them into std table temporarily.

But per a [discussion](https://github.com/apache/calcite/pull/1146#discussion_r274074700) from another ongoing PR (cc @julianhyde), I think maybe we haven't yet come into consensus of changing the file `Parser.jj`. Should we wait for a clear result?
Overall, it looks good but I will do another more careful pass in the following days ;)

Let's discuss in JIRA. Github is not the place for design discussions.
I think it should add some negative test cases.

> Can you add a test case that the join key on inner rel is not distinct?

@hsyuan Can you please clarify what do you mean by join key on inner rel? I did not understand what exactly are you asking for.
In your test case, deptno in table dept is distinct. Can you use another column that is not distinct?

> Why do you want pass factory class instead of just interface AuxiliaryConverter in SqlToRelConverter?

That's actually a good point. SqlToRelConverter requires us to generate one AuxiliaryConverter instance for each SqlFunction (e.g. the List), so it would be very inefficient to pass a reflective class object and then call the newInstance method.

I do have the option to change the AuxiliaryConverter API to do
```
RexNode convert(RexBuilder rexBuilder, RexNode groupCall, RexNode e, SqlFunction sqlCall);
```

With the extra parameter, we can make the AuxiliaryConverter static. This require to change a public interface which I hesitated to do so. 

Any advice?
Let's discuss in JIRA.

> In your test case, deptno in table dept is distinct. Can you use another column that is not distinct?

@hsyuan Thanks for the suggestion. I have added the test case.
